FacilityName: Indorama Ventures Oxides -  PORT NECHES OPERATIONS

_prev_prog_3.Description: G-2 unit reacts propylene oxide with water to form grades of propylene glycol. All the risk management program elements apply.

E-7 Unit: This process area reacts ammonia and diethylene glycol in 3 continuous flow reactors to produce morpholine and diglycolamine. All the risk management program elements apply. The unit contains a storage facility, diking, flares, and process area detectors.

E-4 Unit: This process area reacts ammonia and ethylene oxide to produce ethanolamines. All the risk management program elements apply. The unit contains a storage facility, diking and process area detectors.

E-3, E-6: The OSP (Oxide Specialties Process) area has two units: E-3 and E-6. Both units react ethylene oxide with either nonylphenol or linear alcohols to form nonylphenolethoxylates and linear alcohol ethyoxylates. E-3 unit consists of 3 reactors and associated equipment to charge, react and store products which are non-hazardous. E-6 unit consists of 5 reactors and associated equipment. The E6 unit can also react ethylene oxide and sulfur dioxide to form isethionates. All the risk management program elements apply to the reaction section.  The units contain storage facilities, a moat and process area detectors.

F-4, F-6, F-8 and G-1, G-5, G-6: The F units manufacture ethylene oxide using ethylene and oxygen as reactants over a silver catalyst. The F4 and F6 units produce pure ethylene oxide (EO). However, the F-8 unit dissolves the EO in water prior to sending the aqueous EO to the G units for processing.  The G units react ethylene oxide and water to produce ethylene glycol. G-1 unit receives the cycle water bleed streams produced in the F units and recovers antifreeze-grade glycol. The flammable mixture noted below includes inventories of non-RMP flammable chemicals and RMP flammable chemicals. All the risk management program elements apply. The units contain trenches and process area detectors.

The F8 unit is not online at the time of this submittal, it is currently in the commissioning phase with an anticipated online date of April 2016.

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: DOUBLE MECHANICAL SEALS WITH SEAL POTS ON ALL PUMPS
_prev_prog_3.Description: The F-5, PO/MTBE process area consists of seven sections which are the Feed Preparation, the Peroxidation Reaction, the Epoxidation Reaction, the TBA Purification, the PO Purification, Formate Destruction and the MTBE sections. The Feed Preparation Section consists of purification towers to purify and concentrate isobutane prior to charging the Peroxidation Section for an oxidation reaction.   The Epoxidation Section manufactures propylene oxide.  The Tertiary Butyl Alcohol (TBS) section reclaims and purifies tertiary butyl alcohol for reuse; the Propylene Oxide Section does the same for propylene oxide.  The Formate Destruction section converts the formates generated in the F5 Process prior to sending the feed material to the MTBE section.  The MTBE section manufactures and purifies MTBE. The risk management program elements apply to the F5 unit. The flammable mixture noted below includes inventories of non-RMP flammable chemicals and RMP flammable chemicals. This process unit has associated diked storage tanks.

The Receiving and Shipping (R&S) area consists of product storage tanks; numerous truck and rail car loading/unloading facilities; and a barge and ship loading/unloading dock on the Neches River. Products that are stored in this area are pumped either to processing areas or shipped to customers. The flammable mixture noted below includes inventories of non-RMP flammable chemicals and RMP flammable chemicals. All the risk management program elements apply. The unit contains storage tank diked areas and process area detectors.

The Utility Process Area utilizes chlorine for biological control of the water treatment facilities which includes raw water treatment and cooling water treatment. Chlorine is located at ten (10) separate locations.

The Utility Process Area also utilizes cyclohexylamine at 50% concentration as a water treatment chemical for the boiler feed water system. This material is located in 3 different bulk tanks on site. 

Currently this new material is in one location and under the Threshold Quantity, we anticipated changing the bulk tank volumes and utilizing this material throughout the site in 2016 at which point, the onsite amount, would exceed the threshold quantity.

The A3 Process Unit is divided into the following sections:  The Furnace Section, the Cracked Gas Compression and the Refrigeration and Tower sections. The Furnace section includes from the feed system through the furnaces up through the quench columns. The compression, refrigeration and tower section includes compression, refrigeration and separation equipment downstream of the furnace section as well as an acetylene hydrogenation unit. The A3 process unit includes tankage and ethylene metering skids associated with the A3 Process. All risk management program elements apply.  Only tankage has dikes and only tankage does not have a quench system and excess flow devices. Only the furnace unit does not have tandem seals.  The flammable mixture noted below includes inventories of non-RMP flammable chemicals and RMP flammable chemicals.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
HUNTSMAN LLC - Port Neches Site - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.  Huntsman Port Neches Operations (PNO) Plant is committed to achieving excellence in environmental, health and safety. This is exemplified by the PNO Site having earned the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) VPP Star award for excellence in safety performance at least 3 times.  The Huntsman PNO Site maintains a working Process Safety Management (PSM) program, which implements a series of steps to prevent potential hazards associated with the process and assures a well-trained work force.   The PSM program further implements its policies with onsite procedures and manuals.  Huntsman PNO Site participates with the Jefferson County Local Emergency Planning Commission, Port Neches Fire Department and the Sabine Neches Chiefs Association to develop emergency response plans and participates in cooperative training with these agencies. The facility complies with all applicable codes and standards regarding operating and equipment safety. Huntsman has participated in the past with the Responsible Care; initiative ACC, is committed to the responsible management of chemicals and is an active participant in the International Standards Organization (ISO) 9002 quality management program.   The Director of Manufacturing - PNO is responsible for implementation of the risk management program (RMP).





2.  Regulated Substances. The Huntsman Plant is located in Port Neches, Texas, on 2,400 acres bound by Highway 366 and Hogaboom Road and produces olefins, ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, MTBE, ethylene glycols, propylene glycols, ethanolamines, morpholine/DGA and surfactants.  The PNO Site is divided into nine (9) process areas.  The first area contains the propylene glycol unit G2 .  The second area contains the morpholine/DGA unit E7.  The third area contains the ethanolamines unit E4.  The fourth area contains the surfactants units E3 and E6

.  Ethylene oxide units F4, F6 and F8 and ethylene glycol units G1, G5 and G6 are the fifth area.  The sixth area is PO/MTBE unit known as F5. The seventh area contains the Receiving and Shipping (R&S).  The eighth area contains Utilities.  The ninth area contains the ethylene unit A3. Huntsman's PNO Site has twenty nine (29) regulated flammables and nine (9) regulated toxics at the facility.



The twenty nine (29) flammable substances are:



Ethylene, Ethane, Methane, Isobutane, Propane, Propylene, 2-Methylpropene, Methyl formate, Butane, Acetaldehyde, Pentane, Methyl ether, 2-Butene cis and trans, Hydrogen, Vinyl acetylene, 1-Butene, 1,3-Butadiene, Isoprene, 1,3-Pentadiene, 1-Pentene, 2-Pentene (E) and (Z), 2-Methyl-1-butene, 3-Methyl-1-butene, Acetylene, Ethyl acetylene, Isopentane, Propadiene.

Not all of these chemicals are handled individually at concentrations above their threshold quantity.  Many of them are combined in a feed or process stream with other non-RMP regulated chemicals.



The nine (9) toxic substances are:



Anhydrous and Aqueous Ammonia, Ethylenediamine (EDA), Propylene Oxide (PO), Chlorine, Cyclohexylamine, Peractic Acid, Ethylene Oxide (EO), Sulfur Dioxide (SO2).

All of these chemicals are in a feed or product stream





3.  General accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps.  Following is a brief summary of the elements that Huntsman's PNO Site has implemented to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements outlined by EPA as well as with the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) PSM standard:



Process Safety Information (PSI)

Huntsman's PNO site maintains a compilation of current and accurate written safety information to identify and understand the hazards of the process.  This includes information pertaining to: 

Hazards of regulated substances:  For each regulated substance, there is a Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) which discusses the physical properties of the

chemicals, exposure hazards, the required personal protective equipment and the appropriate first aid and emergency treatment for exposure.

The technology of the process:  Includes a description of process chemistry, safe upper and lower limits of temperature and pressure and analysis of consequences of deviation.

Equipment in the process:  Includes such information as materials of construction, diagrams of the piping and instrumentation, safety systems and design codes.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

Huntsman's PNO Site has performed process hazard analysis on each process to identify the potential hazards, the adequacy of the engineering and administrative controls and the mitigations systems used to minimize those hazards.  The Site utilizes the HAZOP methodology, a recognized and generally accepted method, for identifying and evaluating hazards in the process.  The Site assigns employees to the HAZOP team who are knowledgeable in the HAZOP methodology and the specific process.  The HAZOP team develops recommendations to reduce the potential hazards which, if approved, are implemented within a reasonable period of time.  Hurricanes and inclement weather are not investigated in the PHAs; however, Huntsman does have a Hurricane Procedure and implements this procedure under the threat of a hurricane and inclement weather.



Operating Procedures

Huntsman PNO maintains written operating procedures that are developed in consultation with operators to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities associated with a covered process.  The procedures address steps for all operating phases, safety systems, control measures and precautions to prevent exposures to process hazards.  The procedures are reviewed and revised periodically to ensure their accuracy and completeness.



Training

Huntsman PNO provides initial training as well as refresher training to employees to assure that the required level of skills and knowledge are maintained.  The training

emphasizes safety and health hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices.  All operators receive periodic refresher training.  



Mechanical Integrity (MI)

Huntsman PNO has developed a Risk Based Mechanical Integrity (RBMI) program for maintaining the fixed components of the process (including pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems).  The site has also developed Mechanical Integrity Procedures (MIP) for the emergency shutdown system controls.  The rotating equipment also has a developed mechanical integrity and maintenance strategy program.  The programs are comprised of well-trained personnel who follow maintenance, testing and inspection procedures that ensure proper function of process equipment.



Management of Change (MOC)

Huntsman PNO has established and implemented written procedures and an electronic system to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, and any changes to the facility that affect a covered process.  The procedures assure that, prior to any change, the following issues are considered:  the technical basis for the proposed change, its impact on safety and health, any modifications to operating procedures, the necessary time period for the change, and any authorization requirements.  Employees involved in operating a process, as well as maintenance and contract employees whose job will be affected, are informed of and trained in the change.  If necessary, the process safety information and operating procedures are updated as a part of the management of change process.



Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

Huntsman PNO performs pre-startup safety reviews when an addition or a modification to the facility is made and the MOC evaluation designates a PSSR is required.  The pre-startup safety review confirms, prior to the introduction of highly hazardous chemicals, that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance an

d emergency procedures are in place; and training of employees affected by modifications is complete.



Compliance Audit

Huntsman PNO performs audits of its compliance with the provisions of its Process Safety Management Program.  A team comprised of employees from the Corporate PSM department and other Huntsman facilities, with appropriate knowledge of audit techniques and process safety experience, conduct audits every three years to verify that the procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed.  The findings of the audit team are reviewed and appropriate corrective actions are implemented and tracked until resolved.  



Incident Investigation

Huntsman PNO investigates any incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of covered chemicals.  The investigation is promptly conducted, commencing within 48 hours of any incident.  To perform the investigation, the site has established a procedure to appoint an incident investigation team consisting of persons with the appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident.  A report is prepared at the conclusion of the incident investigation that addresses the incident, the factors that contributed to it, and recommendations resulting from the incident investigation.  The site has established a system to promptly address, document and resolve the incident report findings and recommendations.  Finally, incident reports are reviewed with the affected personnel.



Employee Participation

Huntsman PNO has developed a written action plan for employee participation in all aspects of its Process Safety Management and Risk Management Programs.  The site employees are involved in the PHA reviews, Operating Procedures, Incident Investigations and many other PSM programs.  Huntsman PNO ensures that all employees have access to PHAs and other process safety management information.



Hot Work Permit

Huntsman PNO employs a hot work

permit program for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process (hot work generally involves electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing or similar spark producing operations).  If any hot work is performed near a covered process, the site issues a permit that documents the fire prevention and protection requirements for the operation, the date authorized for hot work, and the object on which the work is performed.  Hot work permits are kept on file until the work is complete.



Contractors

Huntsman PNO has developed procedures for selecting and ensuring that contractors are competent and knowledgeable and can safely perform their work.  The site provides information to contractors about the hazards that may be present in the work area and have developed appropriate safe work practices.  The site also evaluates the safety performance and programs of the contractors as a part of their continued employment.





4.  5 Year Accident History.  The PNO Site has had one (1) reportable RMP incident in the last five years.  The incident involved a release of ethylene oxide that resulted in a Huntsman employee injury. There was no onsite property damage. There were no off-site impacts.





5.  Emergency Response Program.  Huntsman has a written emergency response program that contains procedures to be followed in the case of an accidental release of a regulated substance.  These procedures include steps for informing the public, proper first aid and medical treatment, the proper use of emergency equipment and emergency response training for emergency response employees who perform emergency response duties and to local emergency responders who may be called to assist in emergency response.   The emergency response plan is reviewed annually and updated as necessary.  Huntsman is actively involved with informing local stakeholders about hazardous substances stored and processed on site.  Huntsman participates with the Jefferson County LEPC, Sabine Neches Chiefs

Association and Port Neches Fire Department in assisting local officials in the development of emergency procedures to identify resources, chemicals, contacts and material safety data sheets for participating companies.  The Team Leader of Emergency Response is the emergency contact in the event of an emergency. The Emergency Response Coordinator for this plant is the designated alternate.  The initial response will be provided by Huntsman's on-site fire department.





6.  Planned changes to improve safety.  There are several planned improvements at the PNO Site to reduce the on and offsite impacts of hazardous processes.  Selected ongoing projects include improvements to install and in some cases upgrade the Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) as well as upgrade the process control and instrumentation equipment in many of the units.  There is continual commitment to implement changes, when identified, that will improve the safety of employees and neighbors of the PNO Site as well as projects that enhance safety, environmental protection and protect neighbors from exposure to accidental releases.





7.  Reason for 2017 Re-submittal is due to adding a new waste water treatment chemical to the site that has an RMP listed chemical as a component.  The storage volume of the treatment material and the % of the RPM component will put the facility over the threshold quantity for this new chemical and thus the need for a re-submittal.
